Confirmation bias refers to the tendency to give more weight to information that confirms our existing beliefs or assumptions, when making decisions or forming opinions.
Confirmation bias is the tendency to seek out and give more weight to information that confirms our existing beliefs or assumptions, (while ignoring or downplaying contradictory evidence).
Confirmation bias is the tendency to favor information that supports our pre-existing beliefs or values while ignoring or downplaying contradictory evidence.
Confirmation bias is the tendency to seek out or give more weight to information that confirms our existing beliefs, and to neglect or downplay information that contradicts them.

Confirmation bias is the tendency to seek out or interpret information that confirms our pre-existing beliefs, Aand disregard evidence that contradicts them.
Confirmation bias is the tendency to favor information that confirms our pre-existing beliefs or assumptions, (even when faced with contradictory evidence).
Confirmation bias is the tendency to give more weight to information that confirms our existing beliefs or assumptions, (or even desires) rather than considering alternative perspectives or evidence.
Confirmation bias is the tendency to selectively seek out, and give more weight to information that confirms our existing beliefs or hypotheses, ( ignoring or downplaying contradictory evidence).
Confirmation bias is the tendency to favor information that confirms our pre-existing beliefs or assumptions, while ignoring or downplaying contradictory evidence.
Confirmation bias is the tendency to search for, (or give more weight to) information that confirms our preconceptions, rather than considering alternative perspectives or contradictory evidence.
